TEXT:
TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease presents
   from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s earlier today.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**]. Patient notes that he was doing all prescribed pulmonary
   hygiene, including inexsufflator and was at his baseline until early on
   day of [**Year (4 digits) **] when he felt acutely dyspneic and was noted to have an
   oxygen saturation in the 70s. (ED resident originally reported that
   patient's desaturation was measured on room air; however, patient
   cannot corraborate this information. Patient was discharged with
   instructions to remain on 4L supplemental oxygen at all times.)
   .
   Upon presentation to the ED: T 100.1, HR 76, BP 114/74, RR 22, O2Sat
   100% NRB. Patient was assessed as having a worsened CXR and was given
   prednisone 60 mg, albuterol and ipratropium neb, acetaminophen, Zosyn,
   and tobramycin. Vitals prior to transfer to the ICU were: HR 84, BP
   112/71, RR 14, O2Sat 98% NRB.
   .
   ROS:
   (+)ve: productive cough, dyspnea, back pain (baseline), abdominal pain
   (baseline)
   (-)ve: fever, chills, sweats, constipation, diarrhea, orthopnea,
   paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, sore throat, myalgias, coughing with
   meals or drinking
   .
   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
   1) CML s/p allogeneic stem cell transplant [**2121**] c/b GVHD
   2) Chronic graft vs host disease on immunosuppressants
   -has had chronic abdominal discomfort since transplant that is thought
   to be associated with GVHD
   -bronchiectasis and bronchiolitis obliterans related to GVHD of the
   lung
   3) h/o resistant pseudomonas ([**2124-6-8**]), ESBL E coli ([**2124-5-21**]),
   stenotrophomonas ([**2123-12-23**]) in sputum
   4) Linezolid for VRE bacteremia ([**2124-4-24**]) which he contracted during a
   hospitalization for cellulitis (see d/c summary [**2124-5-4**])
   5) Chronic RUQ pain since [**2113**] (?in addition to GVH-related pain)
   - work up unrevealing
   - on narcotics
   6) GERD w/ Barrett's esophagus
   7) Hypertension
   8) h/o pulmonary embolism in [**5-8**]; DVT [**12-27**]
   9) Compression fractures since the beginning of [**2122**] at T8, T9, T11,
   L1, and L3
   .
   MEDICATIONS: *per discharge on [**10-11**]/209*
   1. Enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: Forty (40) mg Subcutaneous Q12H
   (every 12 hours).
   2. Fentanyl 100 mcg/hr Patch 72 hr Sig: Two (2) patches Transdermal
   every seventy-two (72) hours.
   3. Lidocaine 5 %(700 mg/patch) Adhesive Patch, Medicated Sig: One (1)
   Adhesive Patch, Medicated Topical DAILY (Daily): Apply to left side of
   back for 12 hours daily, then remove for 12 hours.
   4. Lidocaine 5 %(700 mg/patch) Adhesive Patch, Medicated Sig: One (1)
   Adhesive Patch, Medicated Topical DAILY (Daily): Apply to right side of
   back for 12 hours daily, then remove for 12 hours.
   5. Methadone 5 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day)
   6. Methadone 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO QHS (once a day at
   bedtime)
   7. Pregabalin 75 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO QID (4 times a day)
   8. Morphine 30 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as
   needed for pain.
   9. Lorazepam 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: 1-2 Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as
   needed for anxiety.
   10. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1)
   Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).
   11. Amylase-Lipase-Protease 30,000-10,000- 30,000 unit Capsule, Delayed
   Release(E.C.) Sig: Two (2) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO three
   times a day: with meals.
   12. Multi-Vitamin W/Minerals Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a
   day.
   13. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO
   DAILY (Daily)
   14. Acyclovir 200 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO Q12H (every 12
   hours)
   15. Voriconazole 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H (every 12
   hours)
   16. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: Two (2) Tablet,
   Chewable PO three times a day
   17. Budesonide 3 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Capsule,
   Sust. Release 24 hr PO Q 8H (Every 8 Hours)
   18. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day)
   19. Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole 80-400 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet
   PO DAILY (Daily)
   20. Polyethylene Glycol 3350 17 gram/dose Powder Sig: Seventeen (17)
   grams PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for constipation
   21. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times
   a day)
   22. Mycophenolate Mofetil 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QAM once
   a day (in the morning)
   23. Mycophenolate Mofetil 250 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO QPM
   once a day (in the evening)
   24. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: 1-2 Tablets PO every six (6) hours
   as needed for fever or pain
   25. Combivent 18-103 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: Two (2) puffs
   Inhalation every 4-6 hours as needed for shortness of breath or
   wheezing
   26. Tobramycin 300 mg/5 mL Solution for Nebulization Sig: Five (5) ml
   Inhalation [**Hospital1 **] (2 times a day): 4 weeks on, 4 weeks off: started on
   [**10-7**] to end [**11-4**], to restart on [**12-3**]
   27. Albuterol Sulfate 2.5 mg /3 mL (0.083 %) nebulization Sig: Three
   (3) ml Inhalation Q2H (every 2 hours) as needed for wheeze.
   28. Ondansetron 4 mg IV Q8H:PRN nausea
   29. Heparin Flush (10 units/ml) 2 mL IV PRN line flush PICC, heparin
   dependent: Flush with 10mL Normal Saline followed by Heparin as above
   daily and PRN per lumen.
   30. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2
   times a day)
   31. Oxygen 2-4 liters/min by nasal cannula at all times
   32. Cough assist please dispense on mechanical insufflator-exsufflator
   cough assist use: at least twice daily settings: inspiratory pressure
   26, expiratory rpessure 32, pause dialt at 2, AUTO mode, pressures
   depend on seal of mask which is small
   33. Respiratory Therapy Requires frequent deep suctioning at least
   twice a day; [**Hospital1 **] use of acapella PEP device (at bedside); hourly use of
   incentive spirometer (at bedside); at lease twice daily use of
   insuffllator/exsufflator
   34. Diphenhydramine HCl 50 mg/mL Solution Sig: 12.5 mg Injection
   x1 PRN as needed for prior to Gammagard.
   35. Tylenol 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO x1 PRN as needed for
   prior to Gammagard.
   36. Gammagard S/D 10 gram Recon Soln Sig: as directed Intravenous once
   a month: next dose [**2124-10-17**]; premdicate with Tylenol 650mg PO and
   Benadryl 12.5mg IV.
   37. Prednisone 10 mg Tablets, Dose Pack Sig: Four (4) Tablets, Dose
   Pack PO once a day: Until [**10-11**], switch to 30 mg daily until [**10-19**]. Cont. Then, prednisone at 20mg daily indefinitely
   .
   ALLERGIES:
   NKDA
   .
   SOCIAL HISTORY: *from previous hospitalization*
   Lives with his sister and her husband. Previously worked as a
   manufacturing manager, is now on disability.
   Tobacco: quit > 12 years ago; 10 pack-year history
   EtoH: Denies
   Illicits: Denies
   .
   FAMILY HISTORY:
   Father with diabetes mellitus, BPH, alive at 85 yrs
   Mother with h/o breast cancer; d. TIAs and CVD at 75 yrs
   Sister with h/o breast cancer in her 50s, atrial fibrillation
   Two brothers with h/o melanoma

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease presents
   from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s earlier today.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
   #. Hypoxia:
   Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and with multiple
   respiratory pahtogens in recent past. Most likely that patient
   developed a healthcare associated pneumonia given his recent prolonged
   hospitalizations. Last course of antibiotics for HAP was [**2124-9-28**] to
   [**2124-10-5**]. Possible that patient has developed resistance to this
   regimenn, though will treat empirically on past culture data until new
   sputum or BAL samples direct treatment. Aside from an uncomplicated
   bacterial pneumonia, possible that there is an associated pleural
   effusion given new CXR obtained in the ED. Rotation and positioning
   make intepretation difficult, so additional imaging with CT is
   reasonable. Must additionally give consideration to organisms likely to
   infect immunocompromised hosts; however, patient has been on
   prophylaxis with acyclovir, bactrim, voriconazole, and tobramycin.
   After initial treatment for baterial pneumonia and advanced imaging
   with CT, may need to consider BAL for collection of sample to guide
   treatment. As a final point, patient noted by nurse [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **] to be
   without gag reflex and coughed after drinking water, despite multiple
   prior S/S evals, prudent to have patient screened again given poor
   pulmonary reserve and multiple [**Last Name (Titles) **] for hypoxia.
   - CT chest with contrast to determine if new CXR findings are
   atelectasis vs pneumonia vs effusion or some combination of several
   pathologies
   - Cover for healthcare associated pneumonia with vancomycin and zosyn
   (zosyn chosen with regard to prior sensitivities)
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction
   - Sputum culture
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Follow-up influenza screen from ED, though no need to further treat
   with oseltamivir given recent 7 day course from [**2124-10-2**] to
   [**2124-10-8**]
   - Possible need for bronch with BAL to direct treatment as above
   - Speech and swallow consult
   - NPO except medications until formal S/S eval
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:
   At previous [**Year (4 digits) **] patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60
   mg daily and had been titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain:
   Thought to be attributable to GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   Question if chronic respiratory acidosis related to large doses of
   opiates causing respiratory drive suppression and subsequent
   hypoventilation. Patient reporting [**3-26**] pain in abdomen and back at
   presentation.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT:
   Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events. Has been on enoxaparin
   40 mg Q12H for many months; however, a therapeutic dose of enoxaparin
   for this 70 kg gentleman would be 70 mg Q12H.
   - Research records to assess why on enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H

Summary:
Summary of Information:
- The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant in 2121 and developed graft versus host disease (GVHD).
- He presents from a rehabilitation facility after experiencing an episode of hypoxia earlier today.
- The patient has multiple comorbidities, including resistant pseudomonas, ESBL E. coli, stenotrophomonas, VRE bacteremia, pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, chronic abdominal pain, and back pain.
- He is on various medications including immunosuppressants, antibiotics, antivirals, and pain management medications.
- The patient's recent labs show an elevated white blood cell count and platelet count, with other results within normal limits.
- On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued, has scattered coarse crackles with rhonchi and expiratory pleural rub in the lungs, distended abdomen with tenderness, and bilateral lower extremity edema.
- The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 96.9°F, heart rate of 103 bpm, blood pressure of 110/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on 5 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula.
- The patient's recent imaging shows new opacifications in the retrocardiac left lower

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease presents
   from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s earlier today.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
   #. Hypoxia:
   Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and with multiple
   respiratory pahtogens in recent past. The patient may have developed a
   healthcare associated pneumonia given his recent prolonged
   hospitalizations.  On CT, there is collapse of nearly entire LLL and
   some of RLL as well as persistent pleural effusions. No evidence of
   obstruction by mucous plug, so bronch is not likely to be helpful in
   this case.
   - Cover for healthcare associated pneumonia with vancomycin and zosyn
   (zosyn chosen with regard to prior sensitivities).  Day 2 of a 8 day
   course.
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction
   - Try to obtain Sputum culture
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Follow-up influenza screen from ED, though no need to further treat
   with oseltamivir given recent 7 day course from [**2124-10-2**] to
   [**2124-10-8**]
   - Speech and swallow consult
   - NPO except medications until formal S/S eval
   .
   #Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth
   -Will continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn as above
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   -f/u Blood cultures
   .
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:
   At previous admission patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60
   mg daily and had been titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain:
   Thought to be attributable to GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT:
   Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events.
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now pending Speech and Swallow Evaluation

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicating graft versus host disease. He presents from rehab following an episode of hypoxia in the 70s earlier today. The patient has multiple respiratory pathogens in his recent past and may have developed a healthcare-associated pneumonia given his recent prolonged hospitalizations. The CT scan shows collapse of nearly the entire left lower lobe (LLL) and some of the right lower lobe (RLL), along with persistent pleural effusions. There is no evidence of obstruction by mucous plug, so bronchial suctioning is not likely to be helpful in this case.

The patient is currently being covered for healthcare-associated pneumonia with vancomycin and Zosyn (Zosyn chosen with regard to prior sensitivities). This is day 2 of an 8-day course. The patient is also on prednisone 30 mg daily for his chronic GVHD. Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction, obtaining sputum culture, follow-up blood cultures, and a speech and swallow consult have been ordered.

The patient has been given prednisone, Zosyn, and Tobramycin. His current assessment includes hypoxemia, which is concerning for recurrent collapse in the left lung possibly related to mucus plugging. There is also evidence of bilateral erythema and warmth, indicating possible cellulitis.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicating graft versus host disease. He presents from rehab following an episode of hypoxia earlier today. The patient has impaired skin integrity, pain control issues, hypoxemia, and other medical conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemia: The patient may have developed a healthcare-associated pneumonia due to his recent prolonged hospitalizations. He also has underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. The CT scan shows collapse of the entire left lower lobe (LLL) and some of the right lower lobe (RLL), along with persistent pleural effusions. There is no evidence of obstruction by mucous plug, so bronchoscopic intervention may not be helpful in this case.

2. Healthcare-associated pneumonia (HCAP): The patient's recent prolonged hospitalizations and the presence of collapse in the LLL and RLL on CT scan suggest the possibility of HCAP. The patient is currently on a 7-day course of Tamiflu, and empirical treatment with vancomycin and zosyn is being continued.

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and graft versus host disease (GVHD) who presents with impaired skin integrity, pain control, hypoxemia, fever, and chronic GVHD. The patient was discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on October 11th, 2024.

The patient has underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. He may have developed a healthcare-associated pneumonia given his recent prolonged hospitalizations. On CT, there is collapse of nearly the entire left lower lobe (LLL) and some of the right lower lobe (RLL) as well as persistent pleural effusions. No evidence of obstruction by mucous plug, so bronchoscopy is not likely to be helpful in this case.

The patient is currently on a 7-day course of tamiflu from October 2nd to October 8th. Cover for healthcare-associated pneumonia with vancomycin and zosyn (zosyn chosen with regard to prior sensitivities). Day 3 of an 8-day course. The patient is also on prednisone 30 mg daily, pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction, and follow-up sputum culture.

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with severe respiratory failure, chronic obstructive lung disease, and significant impairment in chest wall function. He has been receiving extensive respiratory support. There is no evidence of active significant infection or exacerbation of underlying lung disease upon return from rehab. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 114/65 to 136/83 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 88% on a nasal cannula. The patient's physical examination reveals wheezes and diminished breath sounds, along with soft and distended abdomen. Lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and glucose levels. Imaging shows no evidence of recurrent collapse on chest X-ray.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's severe respiratory compromise and impaired chest wall function may lead to ongoing respiratory failure. Continuous respiratory support will be needed.
2. Infection: The elevated white blood cell count could indicate an underlying infection. Monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting antibiotic therapy accordingly is crucial.
3. Exacerbation of Underlying Lung Disease: The patient's chronic obstructive lung disease may worsen due to the current respiratory failure. Close monitoring and management of his lung condition are necessary.
4. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's skin integrity appears to be compromised. Regular assessment and appropriate wound care are

   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
   #. Hypoxia: Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and
   with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Currently treating
   for HAP.  Has LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT.  No evidence of
   mucous plug obstruction.
   -- Continue HAP coverage with Vanc and Zosyn due to prior
   sensitivities, now on 4 of an 8 day course. (Vanc needs ID approval
   today)
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily until [**2124-10-19**], then 20mg daily after
   reassessment
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction today; MIE being brought over
   - F/u final sputum cx, viral cx
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Will have discussion with patient and family regarding goals of care
   because if he decompensates and needs intubation, it is very likely
   that he would need subsequent trach which he does not want
   - Will need deep suctioning and to be on oxygen at LTACH when
   discharged
   #. Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth.
   WBC stable and remains afebrile.
   -Will continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn as above
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   - F/u Blood cultures
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:  At previous admission
   patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60 mg daily and had been
   titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: Thought to be attributable to
   GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant in 2121. He presented to the ICU with an episode of hypoxia and was discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on October 11, 2124.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including bronchiolitis related to graft versus host disease (GVHD), hypoxia, and hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). He has LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT but no evidence of mucous plug obstruction.

The patient is currently being treated for HAP with vancomycin (Vanc) and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) due to prior sensitivities. He is also on a prednisone taper of 30 mg daily until October 19, then 20 mg daily after reassessment. The patient is also undergoing pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, deep suctioning today; MIE being brought over. Follow-up final sputum culture, viral culture, and blood cultures are pending.

The patient's fever of 100.1F could represent atelectasis, HAP, or cellulitis on the left lower extremity given erythema and warmth. The WBC count is stable and the patient remains afebrile. Empiric treatment with

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) who has been readmitted to the ICU with recurrent hypoxemia. The patient has chronic respiratory compromise due to COPD and chest wall restriction, as well as underlying bronchiolitis. The patient is currently on multiple medications including vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, prednisone, inhaled tobramycin, albuterol, cellcept, bactrim prophylaxis, and pain management medications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Distress/Hypoxemia: The patient's chronic respiratory compromise, underlying bronchiolitis, and COPD increase the risk of recurrent hypoxemia and respiratory distress.
2. GVHD: Although the patient's GVHD appears to be well-controlled, there is still a risk of complications associated with this condition, such as liver dysfunction or gastrointestinal issues.
3. Pain: The patient's pain from compression fractures needs to be managed appropriately to ensure comfort and prevent further complications.
4. Impaired Skin Integrity: There is a risk of skin breakdown or pressure ulcers due to the patient's prolonged bed rest and limited mobility.
5. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state increases the risk of infections, particularly pneumonia given his respiratory symptoms and underlying bronchiolitis.
6. Deep Vein Thrombosis

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**].
   #. Hypoxia: Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and
   with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Currently treating
   for HAP.  Has LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT.  No evidence of
   mucous plug obstruction.
   -- Continue HAP coverage with Vanc and Zosyn due to prior
   sensitivities, now on 5 of an 8 day course.
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily until [**2124-10-19**], then 20mg daily after
   reassessment
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction today; MIE being brought over
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Will have discussion with patient and family regarding goals of care
   because if he decompensates and needs intubation, it is very likely
   that he would need subsequent trach which he does not want
   - address question of possible trach for improved ventilation at night
   - Will need deep suctioning and to be on oxygen at LTACH when
   discharged
   #. Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth.
   WBC stable and remains afebrile.
   -Will continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn as above
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   - F/u Blood cultures
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:  At previous admission
   patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60 mg daily and had been
   titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: Thought to be attributable to
   GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT: Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events.
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Regular diet
   Glycemic Control:  None
   Lines:
   Rt PICC Line - [**2124-10-14**] 10:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: lovenox 40 sq q12h
   Stress ulcer: lansoprazole
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full Code
   Disposition: screen for return to rehab, ICU until then

He presented from a rehabilitation facility with an episode of hypoxia in the 70s. The patient was previously discharged from the ICU to the rehabilitation facility on [**2124-10-11**].

Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, and deep suctioning will be performed today. Follow-up final sputum culture, viral culture, and blood cultures are planned. Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with labored breathing and abdominal pain. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently receiving multiple medications including antibiotics, pain medication, and other ICU medications. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.1 C, heart rate of 68 bpm, blood pressure of 115/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on a nasal cannula. The patient is receiving respiratory support with supplemental oxygen. Physical examination reveals no acute distress, wheezes on respiratory examination, and edema in both lower extremities. The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 194 K/uL, elevated glucose level of 200 mg/dL, and elevated creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL. The patient's coagulation profile is within normal limits.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Complications: The patient's labored breathing and wheezing suggest possible respiratory complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The presence of bilateral lower extremity edema raises concern for DVT, which is being prophylaxed with enoxaparin (lovenox).
3. Infection: The elevated white blood cell count and presence of abdominal pain may indicate an underlying infection, potentially leading to seps

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) and persistent significant respiratory failure. The respiratory failure is attributed to obstructive lung disease, chest wall restriction with vertebral fractures and kyphosis. There is no evidence of ongoing active infection at this time, but there is a small area of left lower lobe (LLL) collapse that persists. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 58 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 121/64 mmHg to 129/78 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on nasal cannula. The patient's weight remains unchanged at 69.3 kg. Fluid balance shows an intake of 2,060 mL and output of 1,390 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 670 mL. The patient is receiving various medications including antibiotics (Vancomycin), pain control medications (Lyrica, Fentanyl, Lidocaine), and GVHD prophylaxis (Prednisone, Cellcept). The patient's lab results show anemia with a hemoglobin level of 8.9 g/dL, elevated white blood cell count of 194 K/uL, slightly low platelet count of 109 mg/dL, normal sodium and potassium levels, and elevated blood glucose levels ranging from 200 mg/dL to 109

   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.

    #. Hypoxia: Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and
   with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Currently treating
   for HAP.  Has LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT.  No evidence of
   mucous plug obstruction.
   -- Continue HAP coverage with Vanc and Zosyn due to prior
   sensitivities, now on 6 of an 8 day course.
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily until [**2124-10-19**], then 20mg daily after
   reassessment.  Given that he is still not able to be weaned to bipap,
   consider keeping at this dose.
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction daily
   - Trial of Bipap at 10/5 today; has used in the past with favorable
   response
   - Follow-up blood cultures
   - Per outpatient pulmonologist, trach is unlikely to improve his
   functional status and may worsen his ability to cough; will hold off on
   trach unless patient needs to be intubated
   - Will need deep suctioning and to be on oxygen at LTACH when
   discharged
   #. Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth.
   WBC stable and remains afebrile.
   -Will continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn as above
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   - F/u Blood cultures
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:  At previous admission
   patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60 mg daily and had been
   titrated down to 30 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned
   taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: Thought to be attributable to
   GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   #. Hx of PE, DVT: Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events.
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H

He presented from rehab after experiencing hypoxia in the 70s. The patient was discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on [**2124-10-11**].

1. Hypoxemia: The patient has underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. He is currently being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). The patient has left lower lobe (LLL) collapse and some right lower lobe (RLL) collapse on CT, but there is no evidence of mucous plug obstruction. To continue HAP coverage with Vancomycin and Zosyn due to prior sensitivities, the patient is on a 6 of an 8-day course. Prednisone is being continued at 30 mg daily until [**2124-10-19**], then 20 mg daily after reassessment. A trial of Bipap at 10/5 today will be attempted, as the patient has used it in the past with favorable response.

Summary:
- The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant in [**2121**]. He is currently being treated for graft versus host disease (GVHD).
- The patient presented from rehab with an episode of hypoxia in the 70s.
- He was discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on [**2124-10-11**].
- The patient's current conditions include impaired skin integrity, pain control (acute and chronic pain), hypoxemia, fever, CML status post bone marrow transplants (BMTs), chronic GVHD, chronic abdominal pain, and back pain.
- The patient's medical history includes pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Potential medical complications:
1. Hypoxemia: The patient has underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. He is currently being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). There is LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT. No evidence of mucous plug obstruction.
   - Continue HAP coverage with Vanc and Zosyn due to prior sensitivities, now on 6 of an 8-day course.
   - Continue prednisone 30 mg daily until [**2124-10-19**], then 20 mg daily after reassessment.
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction daily.
   - Trial of Bipap at 10/5 today; has used in the past with favorable response.
   - Follow-up blood cultures.
   - Possible to try bipap later today depending on pulmonary status.

2. Fever: The patient has a low-grade fever of 100.1F, which could represent atelectasis, HAP, or cellulitis on the lower extremity given erythema and warmth.
   - Will continue empiric treatment with Vanc and Zosyn as above.
   - Trend WBC counts and fever curves.
   - Follow-up blood cultures.

3. Chronic GVHD: The patient has chronic GVHD, which is causing chronic abdominal pain and back pain.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil.
   - Continue prednisone at 30 mg daily and reassess prior to planned taper down to 20 mg daily on [**2124-10-19**].

4. HAP: The patient is being treated for HAP with Vanc and Zosyn due to prior sensitivities.
   - Continue HAP coverage with Vanc and Zosyn as above.

5. DVT/PE: The patient has a history of PE and DVT.
   - Continue enoxap

Other lab results are within normal limits.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). The patient presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s. He was discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on [**2124-10-11**].

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxemia: The patient has underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and has had multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. He is currently being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). The patient has left lower lobe (LLL) collapse and some right lower lobe (RLL) collapse on CT scan. There is no evidence of mucous plug obstruction. Coverage for HAP with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam has been completed, and the patient is now being discharged. Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, and deep suctioning daily will be continued. Follow-up blood cultures will also be done.

2. Fever: The patient has a low-grade fever of 100.1°F, which could represent atelectasis, HAP, or cellulitis on the left lower extremity given the erythema and warmth. The white blood cell (W

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). The patient presented from rehab with an episode of hypoxia in the 70s. He was discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on [**2124-10-11**].

The patient's current conditions include impaired skin integrity, pain control (acute pain, chronic pain), and hypoxemia. He has underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. The patient is currently being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and has left lower lobe collapse and some right lower lobe collapse on CT. There is no evidence of mucous plug obstruction.

The plan includes continuing HAP coverage with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam due to prior sensitivities, now on a 7-day course. Considering a decrease in prednisone dosage to 20 mg daily. Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, and deep suctioning daily. The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of obstructive lung disease, undergoing outpatient bronchial lavage (BAL) for graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) post bone marrow transplant (BMT) for chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). The patient has significant chest wall restriction due to vertebral fractures and pain. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure.

24-hour events:
- The patient's oxygen saturation (SpO2) decreased to 84% despite increased oxygen flow rate during the initiation of BIPAP (bi-level positive airway pressure) therapy. Prior to intervention, the patient's SpO2 was 96%. This suggests significant zone 1 physiology and preferential shunt to underventilated areas at the bases. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant in [**2121**] and developed graft versus host disease (GVHD).
- The patient presented from rehab with an episode of hypoxia and was discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on [**2124-10-11**]. He was readmitted with hypoxia.
- The patient has impaired skin integrity, pain control (acute and chronic pain), and hypoxemia.
- He has a history of CML treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicating GVHD.
- The patient's current condition includes hypoxia due to underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and previous respiratory pathogens. He has left lower lobe (LLL) collapse and right lower lobe (RLL) collapse on computed tomography (CT), but no evidence of mucous plug obstruction.
- The patient finished a course of antibiotics and is undergoing pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive spirometry, acapella valve, and deep suctioning daily.
- The outpatient pulmonologist believes that tracheostomy may worsen the patient's ability to cough and is holding off on it unless the patient needs to be intubated.
- The patient also has a low-grade fever of 100.1°F, which could represent atelectasis, healthcare-associated pneumonia (HAP), or cellulitis on the lower extremity given the erythema and warmth.
- His WBC count is stable, and he remains afebrile.
- Trend WBC counts and fever curves, and follow-up blood cultures are planned.
- The patient is being treated for chronic GVHD with prednisone taper and mycophenolate mofetil. Prophylaxis with Bactrim, voriconazole, and tobramycin is also being continued.
- The patient is on enoxaparin for prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
- He continues to experience chronic abdominal pain and back pain, which are thought to be attributable to GVHD after a negative prior work-up.
- The patient's pain management regimen includes fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches, and pregabalin.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemia: The patient's underlying bronchiolitis and previous respiratory pathogens may lead to persistent hypoxemia.
2. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient has impaired skin integrity, which increases the risk of infection and delayed wound healing.
3. Chronic Pain: The patient's chronic abdominal pain and back pain may hinder his recovery and increase the risk of complications related to immobility.
4. GVHD: The patient's history of GVHD may lead to ongoing inflammation and damage to organs such as the lungs, abdomen

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive lung disease, undergoing bone marrow transplantation for chronic myeloid leukemia. He has been experiencing respiratory failure and is currently in the ICU. The patient's medical history includes GVHD (graft-versus-host disease), bronchiectasis, and recurrent respiratory infections. He has been on mechanical ventilation but has shown poor tolerance to BiPAP (non-invasive positive airway pressure). The patient's current condition includes severe pain due to vertebral fractures, extensive skin tears, and impaired skin integrity.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern and can lead to further deterioration in his oxygenation and ventilation. Close monitoring and aggressive management of his respiratory status are crucial.
2. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to bone marrow transplantation and GVHD increases his risk of developing infections. Proper infection control measures and vigilant monitoring for any signs of infection are essential.
3. Pain Management: The patient's severe pain needs to be addressed promptly to improve his comfort and overall well-being. Adequate analgesia should be provided to manage both acute and chronic pain.
4. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's extensive skin tears and impaired skin integrity put him at risk for skin breakdown and potential infections. Proper wound care and regular assessment of the skin are necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Fluid Imbalance: The patient's fluid

The patient is a 58-year-old male with significant obstructive lung disease, obstructive bronchiolitis (OB) with graft versus host disease (GVHD) following bone marrow transplantation (BMT) for chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). He also has chest wall restriction due to vertebral fractures and pain. The patient is currently managed with frequent suctioning and chest physiotherapy limited to flutter valve due to good tolerance. Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) or BiPAP has not been successful.

The patient has a history of recurrent respiratory failure and bronchiectasis. He has been weaned from nasal rapid flow (NRB) to nasal cannula (NC) and looks at his poor baseline on standing tobramycin nebulizers for pseudomonas suppression. The patient experienced a significant oxygen desaturation event on 12/20 and failed the trial of BiPAP. He was supposed to be transferred to the oncology floor yesterday but was unable to do so due to the desaturation event. Today, the patient has lower oxygen saturation (sats) and higher oxygen requirements, possibly due to a plug. He is currently on home prophylactic antibiotics including bactrim, [Doctor First Name] nebs, and voriconazole. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate of 66 bpm, blood pressure of 118/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His general appearance is no acute distress, ill-appearing, severe kyphosis. Physical examination findings include normal eye and conjunctiva, normocephalic head, ears, nose, and throat, normal heart sounds, difficult to auscultate due to loud rhonchorous lung sounds, no significant edema in extremities, warm skin with extensive skin tears, and attentive neurologic status.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 5.4 K/uL, hematocrit of 28.7%, platelet count of 94 K/uL, creatinine of 0.6 mg/dL, total carbon dioxide of 46 mmol/L, blood glucose of 200 mg/dL, and electrolyte levels within normal ranges. Other lab results including PT/PTT/INR, differential, lactic acid, calcium, magnesium, phosphate, and fluid analysis are provided.

The patient's medical issues include impaired skin integrity, pain control (acute and chronic pain), and hypoxemia. The plan includes increasing the use of incentive spirometry and flutter valve, needs suction [Hospital1], and addressing other issues per resident note on 10/21. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition, glycemic control, lines (PICC line), prophylaxis (DVT and stress ulcer), and comments regarding communication, code status, and disposition.

   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**] and then readmitted with hypoxia.
    #. Hypoxia: Patient with underlying bronchiolitis related to GVHD and
   with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Has LLL collapse
   and some RLL collapse on CT.  No evidence of mucous plug obstruction.
   Finished course of antibiotics.
   - Pulmonary hygiene with mechanical in-exsufflator, incentive
   spirometry, acapella valve, deep suction daily
 have discussed q2h
   acapella valve usage
   - Per outpatient pulmonologist, trach is unlikely to improve his
   functional status and may worsen his ability to cough; will hold off on
   trach unless patient needs to be intubated
   - Will need deep suctioning and to be on oxygen at LTACH/floor when
   discharged
   - Plan for goals of care discussion on Monday; will contact outpatient
   providers to see when they are available
   #. Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth.
   WBC stable and remains afebrile. Empiric Vanc/Zosyn stopped.
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   - F/u stool Cx
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:  At previous admission
   patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60 mg daily and had been
   titrated down to 20 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue ppx with Bactrim, voriconazole, tobramycin
   - Will start azithromycin prophylaxis (500mg daily x 6 days, then 250mg
   on MWF)
   - Continue prednisone at 20 mg daily
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: Thought to be attributable to
   GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   - will consider increasing prn morphine or change to drip
   #. Hx of PE, DVT: Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events.
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Regular diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   Stress ulcer: lansoprazole

   Disposition: Consider callout to BMT

Summary of the Progress Note:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant in [**2121**]. He presented from rehab with an episode of hypoxia and was previously discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on [**2124-10-11**]. The patient was readmitted due to hypoxia and has been in the ICU since then.

The patient's current complaints include labored breathing and pain in his abdomen and back. His allergies include no known drug allergies. The patient has been receiving multiple antibiotics including Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn), Vancomycin, Acyclovir, Bactrim (SMX/TMP), and Voriconazole.

Vital signs show a temperature of 36.7°C (98.1°F) with a current temperature of 35.6°C (96°F), heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 103/57mmHg to 134/64mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's weight remains unchanged at 69.3 kg.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and complications from an allogeneic stem cell transplant. He presented to the ICU with hypoxia and has been diagnosed with bronchiolitis related to graft versus host disease (GVHD). The patient's respiratory function has declined over the past 48 hours, and he is becoming more difficult to suction. He requires a discussion about goals of care and potential tracheostomy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient's underlying bronchiolitis and multiple respiratory pathogens may lead to worsening hypoxia.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a new onset of atrial fibrillation, likely due to hypoxia and increased catecholamine surge.
3. Fever: The patient has a low-grade fever, which could represent atelectasis, hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), or cellulitis on the lower extremities.
4. Chronic GVHD: The patient's history of chronic GVHD may contribute to various complications such as chronic abdominal pain and back pain.
5. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)/Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient has a history of PE and DVT, for which he is receiving enoxaparin prophylaxis.
6. Infection: The patient may be at risk for further infections due to his immunocompromised state and prolonged ICU stay.

Please note that this summary and potential medical complications are based on the provided progress note. It is important to consult with the healthcare team for a comprehensive assessment and appropriate management.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a chief complaint of atrial fibrillation (AFib) and impaired mobility. The patient's condition has been unstable, with episodes of rapid ventricular response requiring treatment with metoprolol and diltiazem. Fluid boluses have been administered totaling 1.5 liters. The patient is experiencing thickened secretions requiring frequent suctioning.

The patient has no known drug allergies and is currently receiving multiple medications, including metoprolol, diltiazem, enoxaparin (Lovenox), and morphine sulfate.

Review of systems remains unchanged from admission except for the AFib. Vital signs show tachycardia with a heart rate of 112 bpm, hypotension with a blood pressure of 91/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92% on high-flow nasal cannula. The patient's temperature is mildly low at 35.3°C. Physical examination reveals poor air movement, diffuse rhonchi that clear after suctioning, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally with diminished distal pulses.

Lab results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 22300/uL, elevated creatinine at 1.7 mg/dL, and elevated blood glucose levels ranging from 81-200 mg/dL. Coagulation studies are abnormal

The patient's physical examination shows signs of exhaustion, irregularly irregular heart rhythm, poor air movement, and diffuse rhonchi that clear after suctioning. The patient's vital signs include a heart rate of 112 bpm, blood pressure of 91/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and temperature of 35.3 C. 1. Hypoxemia: The patient's SpO2 is 92%, indicating a potential risk of low oxygen levels in the blood.

   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on
   [**2124-10-11**] and then readmitted with hypoxia.
    #. Hypoxia: Patient with underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis
   related to GVHD and with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past.
   Has LLL collapse and some RLL collapse on CT.   Finished course of
   antibiotics.  Patient
s respiratory function has declined over the past
   48 hours, he is becoming more difficult to suction; possibly having
   mucus plugging and decreased recruitment secondary to fatigue could all
   be contributing to his hypoxia.  Less likely to be in CHF, as patient
   appears hypovolemic clinically.  This AM, pt made aware that intubation
   would lead to tracheostomy and agreed to proceed.
   - Currently intubated on volume support; will attempt to decrease FiO2
   and possibly switch to PS later today
   - Continue aggressive suctioning, atrovent and albuterol nebs
   - Send sputum culture as patient could have recurrent pulm infection
   - IP contact[**Name (NI) **] for tacheostomy
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation; New onset this admission, although per patient
   has had episodes in the past.  Likely due to hypoxia and increased
   catcholamine surge.  More responsive to diltiazem than metoprolol ->
   changed to diltiazem.  Pt also appears volume down this morning, with
   decreased urine output
   - bolus 1 L NS
   - Can consider increasing diltiazem in PM if fluid repletion does not
   improve tachycardia
   .
   #. Fever: In [**Name (NI) **], pt. with low grade fever of 100.1F, could represent
   atelectasis vs. HAP vs. cellulitis on LE given erythema and warmth.
   WBC stable and remains afebrile. Empiric Vanc/Zosyn stopped.  Pt
   remains afebrile but respiratory function has declined with increased
   secretions.
   - Sputum Cx today
   -Trend WBC counts and fever curves
   - F/u stool Cx
   #. CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD:  At previous admission
   patient was started on a prednisone taper of 60 mg daily and had been
   titrated down to 20 mg daily.
   - Continue mycophenolate mofetil
   - Continue ppx with Bactrim, voriconazole, tobramycin, acyclovir
   - Will start azithromycin prophylaxis (500mg daily x 6 days, then 250mg
   on MWF); today is day 2.
   - Continue prednisone at 20 mg daily
   #. Chronic abdominal pain and back pain: Thought to be attributable to
   GVHD after negative prior work-up.
   - Continue fentanyl patch, methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches,
   pregabalin
   - will consider increasing prn morphine or change to drip
   #. Hx of PE, DVT: Patient with multiple prior thrombotic events.
   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant and complicating graft versus host disease. He presented from rehab with an episode of hypoxia in the 70s. The patient was discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on 10/11/2024 and then readmitted with hypoxia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient has underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD and multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. He has a left lower lobe collapse on CT and finished a course of antibiotics. His respiratory function has declined over the past 48 hours, and he is becoming more difficult to suction. Possible contributing factors include mucus plugging, decreased recruitment secondary to fatigue, and less likely to be in congestive heart failure (CHF) due to hypovolemia.

2. Atrial Fibrillation (AF): The patient had new-onset AF this admission, although he has had episodes in the past. It is likely due to hypoxia and increased catecholamine surge. The patient responded better to diltiazem than metoprolol, so the medication was changed to diltiazem. The patient also appears volume depleted this morning with decreased urine output.

3. Fever: The patient had a low-grade fever of 100.

The patient presented from rehab with an episode of hypoxia in the 70s and was readmitted to the ICU due to hypoxia.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Hypoxia: The patient has underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD, with multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. The patient has left lower lobe (LLL) collapse and some right lower lobe (RLL) collapse on CT. The patient finished a course of antibiotics and is now intubated and sedated. The plan is to continue aggressive suctioning, atrovent, and albuterol nebs. A tracheostomy is likely to happen today, and an arterial line (A-line) may be needed soon.

2. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing hypotension, which is likely related to sedation and the peri-intubation period. The plan is to wean the pressor as tolerated.

The patient presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s and was previously discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on [**2124-10-11**]. He was readmitted with hypoxia.

The patient has several medical complications and conditions, including:

1. Hypoxia: The patient's underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to graft versus host disease (GVHD) and with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. The patient finished a course of antibiotics but is now intubated and sedated.

2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient developed new-onset atrial fibrillation this admission, likely due to hypoxia and increased catecholamine surge. The patient responded better to diltiazem than metoprolol and has since converted to sinus rhythm.

3. Fever: The patient's white blood cell count remains stable and is afebrile since admission. Empiric Vancomycin/Zosyn was stopped.

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of malignancy who is currently in the ICU. He underwent percutaneous tracheostomy today and is planned for a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tomorrow. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure of 99/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on FiO2 40%. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a respiratory support mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow. The patient's ABG shows a pH of 7.35, PCO2 of 35 mmHg, and PO2 of 104 mmHg.

The patient's labs reveal a white blood cell count of 5.1 K/uL, hemoglobin level of 7.6 g/dL, platelet count of 188 K/uL, sodium level of 135 mg/dL, potassium level of 3.8 mEq/L, chloride level of 104 mEq/L, and creatinine level of 0.6 mg/dL. The sputum gram stain shows >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field, with 2+ gram-positive cocci in pairs. The respiratory culture is pending.

The patient's physical examination is significant for impaired airway clearance

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, not ARDS, and is currently intubated on AC with volume control ventilation. He was successfully weaned from FiO2 and PEEP yesterday, but the main barrier to extubation is now sedation. The patient will continue aggressive suctioning, atrovent, and albuterol nebs, and will follow up with sputum culture.

2. Hypotension: The patient experienced hypotension likely related to sedation and the peri-intubation period. However, it has improved and pressor support has been stopped.

3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient developed new-onset atrial fibrillation this admission, likely due to hypoxia and increased catecholamine surge. It was initially more responsive to diltiazem than metoprolol, so the patient was changed to diltiazem. The patient has now converted to

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). The patient presented from rehab with an episode of hypoxia to the 70s and was discharged from the ICU to a high-level rehab facility on [**2124-10-11**]. He was readmitted with hypoxia. 

The patient has underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD and multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past. He has left lower lobe (LLL) collapse and some right lower lobe (RLL) collapse on CT. He finished a course of antibiotics and is now intubated on assisted control ventilation with volume control, successfully weaned FiO2 and PEEP yesterday. 

The patient has several medical complications including respiratory failure, hypotension, atrial fibrillation (AFIB), impaired gait and muscle performance, impaired transfers, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, impaired airway clearance, impaired balance, impaired skin integrity, chronic pain, hypoxemia, and a history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

The patient's current treatment plan includes aggressive suctioning, atrovent and albuterol nebs, f/u sputum Cx; will hold off on abx until culture

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) treated with allogeneic stem cell transplant and complications of graft versus host disease (GVHD). He presented from rehabilitation with an episode of hypoxia in the 70s and was admitted to the ICU. 

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, hypotension, atrial fibrillation (AFIB), impaired gait, muscle performance, transfers, aerobic capacity/endurance, airway clearance, balance, impaired skin integrity, pain control, and hypoxemia. 

The patient's medical history includes episodes of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT), chronic abdominal pain and back pain thought to be related to GVHD, and previous admissions to the ICU.

The patient has undergone several interventions and treatments, including percutaneous tracheostomy, placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG), weaning off sedation and ventilator support, and changes in medication including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and pain management.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory complications: Given the patient's history of bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD, along with previous respiratory infections, there is a risk of further respiratory complications such as pneumonia or worsening of

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])/HYPOXEMIA: Patient with
   underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD and with
   multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Has LLL collapse and

   - Continue enoxaparin 40 mg Q12H
   .
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK): Likely related to sedation and

   .

   - f/u Sputum Cx

Summary of Progress Note:
- Patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplant in 2021 and complicated by graft versus host disease (GVHD).
- The patient presented to the hospital with hypoxia and was admitted to the ICU.
- He was discharged from the ICU to a rehabilitation facility but was readmitted with hypoxia.
- The patient has underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD and multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past.
- He has tracheostomy in place and is currently on ventilatory support.
- The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, acute hypoxemia, pain control, atrial fibrillation, depression, and other chronic conditions such as CML s/p BMTs, complicated by chronic GVHD, history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT), hypotension, fever, anemia, and others.
- The patient is receiving various treatments including antibiotics, mycophenolate mofetil, prophylactic medications, and tube feeds.
- The patient's family has been informed about the current situation, and the code status is set to full code.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD, along with multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past

   58 yo M with history of CML treated with allogeneic stem cell
   transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease who
   presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s.
   Patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])/HYPOXEMIA: Patient with
   underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD and with
   multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. Has LLL collapse and
   some RLL collapse on CT.   Finished course of antibiotics.  Now with
   Trach on ventilator.  [**Month (only) 60**] also have pulmonary edema in the setting of
   microocclusive disease
   - Switched to PS  yesterday, with RSBI 27, should do SBT again on trach
   collar after transfer to rehab
   - Continue aggressive suctioning, atrovent and albuterol nebs
   - sputum Cx from [**10-26**] cancelled.  [**10-24**] shows respiratory flora; no
   need for abx at this time
 PAIN CONTROL (ACUTE PAIN, CHRONIC PAIN): Has chronic abdominal pain
   and back pain thought to be attributable to GVHD after negative prior
   work-up.  Also with multiple compression fractures on his back.
   - Continue methadone, morphine, lidocaine patches, pregabalin via PEG
   - Have switched to dilaudid PCA overnight to assess pain needs more

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplant in [**2121**] and complicating graft versus host disease. He presented from rehab following an episode of hypoxia to the 70s. The patient was discharged from the ICU to the high level rehab facility on [**2124-10-11**] and then readmitted with hypoxia.

The patient has underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD and with multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. He has left lower lobe (LLL) collapse and some right lower lobe (RLL) collapse on CT. The patient finished his course of antibiotics and is now on a tracheostomy tube ventilator.

The patient's pain control is being managed with methadone PCA, dilaudid PCA, lidocaine patches, and pregabalin via PEG. The patient requires approximately 7 mg of dilaudid since 2 pm yesterday but states that his pain could still be better controlled. Amitriptyline has also been started.

Summary:
The patient is a 67-inch tall, 112.3 kg individual admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and hypoxemia. They have a history of chronic pain, depression, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, alteration in nutrition, impaired gait, impaired muscle performance, impaired transfers, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, impaired airway clearance, impaired balance, and impaired skin integrity. The patient is currently on PCA using dilaudid 0.37 q10mins, amitriptyline 10mg po at night, lansoprazole (Prevacid), enoxaparin (Lovenox), and various other medications. Vital signs include a temperature of 37.2 C, heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 94/57 to 112/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's weight has increased from 69.3 kg at admission to 112.3 kg currently. Fluid balance shows an input of 1,076 mL and output of 1,795 mL over the past 24 hours. The patient's labs indicate an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, slightly elevated potassium levels, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's respiratory support consists of CPAP/PSV with a tidal volume of 346 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant in 2121 and developed graft versus host disease (GVHD). He presented to the ICU with respiratory failure and hypoxia. The patient has bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD, multiple respiratory pathogens in the recent past, left lower lobe (LLL) collapse, and right lower lobe (RLL) collapse on CT.

The patient was treated with antibiotics but now shows no need for further antibiotic therapy as sputum culture from 10/24 shows respiratory flora. He continues to be on mechanical ventilation through a tracheostomy tube with CPAP/PSV mode, with a respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 27. The patient's blood pressure has been in the 70s around 11 pm, and a 500cc bolus was given, resulting in improvement. Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplant in 2021 and complicating graft versus host disease (GVHD). He presented from rehab with an episode of hypoxia and was admitted to the ICU. The patient has underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD, multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past, and pulmonary edema in the setting of microocclusive disease. He is currently on ventilatory support through a tracheostomy tube and is being weaned off sedation. The patient also has chronic abdominal pain and back pain thought to be attributable to GVHD after negative prior work-up. He has multiple compression fractures on his back. The patient has new-onset atrial fibrillation (AFib) likely due to hypoxia and increased catecholamine surge. He has converted to sinus rhythm and is being restarted on diltiazem. The patient appears withdrawn since admission and more so after intubation/trach, and has started on citalopram and amitriptyline. He has a history of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He continues on enoxaparin prophylaxis. The patient's blood pressure has improved and the pressor has been stopped. He is currently afebrile, but his white blood cell (WBC)

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant in 2121 and developed graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). He presented to the hospital with respiratory failure and hypoxia, and was previously discharged from the ICU to a rehabilitation facility. Upon readmission, he is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation through a tracheostomy. The patient has multiple comorbidities, including bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD, pulmonary edema, chronic abdominal pain, back pain, atrial fibrillation, and depression.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, indicating ongoing respiratory failure. The underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD, along with the presence of pulmonary edema, increase the risk of further respiratory complications.
2. Infection: Despite recent antibiotics, there is a risk of developing new infections due to the patient's immunocompromised state and prolonged intubation.
3. Thrombosis: The patient has a history of pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis, increasing the risk of thrombotic events while in the ICU.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin levels are trending down, suggesting anemia. Further investigation and management are needed to address this issue.
5. Pain Management:

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant in 2021. The patient presented to the ICU with respiratory failure and hypoxemia. He had been discharged from the ICU previously but was readmitted due to hypoxia. The patient has underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to graft versus host disease (GVHD) and has had multiple respiratory pathogens in recent past. The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure/acute hypoxemia, pain control, atrial fibrillation, depression, and complications related to GVHD.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure/Acute Hypoxemia: The patient's underlying bronchiolitis and bronchiectasis related to GVHD, along with multiple respiratory pathogens, put him at risk for recurrent respiratory infections and further deterioration of respiratory function.

2. Graft Versus Host Disease (GVHD): The patient's history of GVHD increases the risk of developing chronic GVHD complications such as liver dysfunction, gastrointestinal disturbances, skin problems, and pulmonary issues.

3. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to stem cell transplantation and ongoing immunosuppressive therapy increases the risk of opportunistic infections, including bacterial, viral, and fungal infections.

4. Thrombotic Events: The patient's history of pulmonary embolism and deep vein throm

Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male with respiratory failure, hypoxemia, and pain control issues. The patient's past medical history, social history, and review of systems are unchanged from admission except for fatigue, dry mouth, and abdominal pain. The patient is currently receiving PCA for pain management and has been tolerating trache mask for short periods of time.

Vital signs show a temperature of 37.5°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, blood pressure of 90/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 of 40% and has a respiratory system compliance of 27.

Physical examination reveals no acute distress, poor dentition, normocephalic head, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiovascular examination shows normal heart sounds, no murmurs, and no peripheral edema. Respiratory examination shows clear breath sounds with crackles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Musculoskeletal examination reveals muscle wasting and inability to stand. Neurologic examination shows attentive behavior, oriented to person, place, and time, and follows simple commands.

Laboratory results indicate anemia, elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, elevated creatinine, elevated potassium, and elevated liver enzymes. The patient's blood glucose levels have been fluctuating.
